of a challenge because my background's not in Tech at all so it's a huge learning curve for me and also it's a
slow overall indigenous representation in the tech space roughly four percent
for Maori around 2.5 for Pacific Islanders and further underrepresented
groups such as women sitting around 27 there's a lot of groundwork for us to do
in terms of how we can bridge that Gap and also in general just really limited awareness of people around what open
source and Cloud even is and how it might benefit communities so from there my team and I we adopted
a tiara Maori or Maori worldview approach with a modified design think
methodology to better understand that space what are what are the barriers and
sticking points of people and perhaps ideating some solutions so we created
things like learning resources and providing Partners into training and certification marketing strategies and
even providing professional development of local high school teachers most critical to that was working alongside
local Community Education providers industry and government to help bring to that Gap we took part

teachers businesses families home schoolers whoever just to introduce them
to things like Linux and open source and Raspberry Pi and kubernetes and for a
lot of people it was their first time we've been hearing some of these sorts of things so really good learning for us in terms of what better steps do we need
to take to help you know how talk about how career options in that direction
might be a little bit more attainable and accessible accessible for people from there we developed our own event
called straight to the source which is a lot more focused we're working with the local girls high school to try and
understand how we could strengthen the connection between education industry so we're talking
about certifications in kubernetes things like women and Linux and LFX
men's or ships and again working alongside local businesses Council and universities to try and
